TopicTitle: Devnote Tuesday: A change of pace

Articles.Content:
On 26.1.2016 at 11:12 PM, SQUAD said:

The new PartTools uses Unity AssetBundles rather than .mu files and will therefore allow every standard Unity object to be included in mods.

 

So, what does this mean for existing part mods? Will they be useless in 1.1, or is there any way to continue use of older mod parts?

 

Regards

Tantalus

On 1/26/2016 at 10:12 PM, SQUAD said:

The biggest change in pace is no doubt for Ted, who has taken on the task of representing Kerbal Space Program in the mainstream UK media. As we mentioned a few weeks ago, space is all the rage in the UK with astronaut Tim Peake currently aboard the International Space Station. Ted is currently in London and preparing to record radio and TV interviews which will be aired throughout the UK in the next week.

Anyone have any idea what channels this stuff will be aired on? Excited to see KSP get more mention on the TV.

1 hour ago, Tantalus said:

So, what does this mean for existing part mods? Will they be useless in 1.1, or is there any way to continue use of older mod parts?

They said that the old .mu files would still work in the same paragraph, and so old part mods should still work

Quote

The KSPedia is a new feature for 1.1, and after Dave (TriggerAu)’s design work Mike (Mu) is now working to get the backend system into a working state and into the main project. -snip- .The new PartTools uses Unity AssetBundles rather than .mu files and will therefore allow every standard Unity object to be included in mods. -snip- .The old Mu files and loading methods will of course still be supported.

Emphasis mine.

Edited January 29, 2016 by Norpo
clarified, misuse of literally is literally weird

As soon as 1.1 is released I think that will be the time for a visual and audio overhaul for all of the parts and for the planets themselves. Then put life support into the game. It has to be done.

Audio: Simulate what sound would really be like if we were to travel faster than the speed of sound and in vacuum of space. Proper rocket, rcs and airbreathing engine sounds please. IVA sounds. Comms chatter. 

Visual: Clouds. All of the rocket and airplane parts need a do over (just make Vens parts stock). Rocket plume, ground and water textures, condensation effects, planet reflection, moon shadows, rcs jet visuals, auroras, sandstorms, part reflections etc. The whole game needs a serious makeover that mimics vens parts. So do the animations... engine gimbals are way too jittery, make them smoother and slower. 

Part functionality: I hate seeing jet engines that clip into fuel tanks etc without logical air flow into the part. Kerbals should NOT be able to transfer through the smallest docking port nor should they be able to transfer through blocked internals on a spacecraft. Batteries placed at the edge of structural beams would not be able to provide power to core modules. It's time to add functionality to the utility, structural, comms and science parts. 

Parts: Electric wires; act like fuel lines but for batteries and solar panels. Putting solar panels onto I beams with not logical connection to its intended module needs to stop. It doesn't make sense and leads to sloppy and illogical designs.

40 minutes ago, TeeGee said:

a whole lotta stuff

I think stuff like wires and life support should be added once an average computer can run 200+ part ships without lag.

(Who says wires can't be run, say, along the inside edges of a truss?)

3 hours ago, Norpo said:

They said that the old .mu files would still work in the same paragraph, and so old part mods should still work

Hell, must have skipped that part. Thanks a lot.

14 hours ago, KerbonautInTraining said:

I think stuff like wires and life support should be added once an average computer can run 200+ part ships without lag.

(Who says wires can't be run, say, along the inside edges of a truss?)

Wires take close to zero space same with pipes for RCS and fuel for fuel cells.
Then designing stuff with lots of pipes like oil platforms pipes larger than 4 cm is designed as they have to be ordered with bends, smaller ones are bend during building.
An better management system would do the tricks. Let you set up rules in an control system, science systems are not allowed to draw more than 75-90% of power the rest is an reserve for ship. 
Also set rules for the fuel cell like do not run if non fuel cell power production is larger than consummation and battery level is over 25%
Drain batteries in landing stage first. 
Same for RSC including not draw monoprop from lander and do not use its RSC then docked to mothership.

18 hours ago, TeeGee said:

As soon as 1.1 is released I think that will be the time for a visual and audio overhaul for all of the parts and for the planets themselves. [...]

Honestly, I can wait on the flourishes AFTER they release a complete, stable, mostly bug-free, core-features complete game. Audio helps with immersion, yes (example from another game would be the audio overhaul in Terraria v1.3), but that can wait (the Terraria example I used took about 4 years, from v1.0.6.1 to the current v1.3.0.x.)

I can wait on most of the visual as well, as long as what I see on my screen correlates to what I expect of the game's functionality. If anything, I'm more concerned with the models than the textures and eye-candy. Though last I recall, PorkJet is doing a pass on the rocket part as well this time around, no? The stock FLT-800 tank (really, any of the stock 1.25m tanks) irks me to no end with the its model.

Anyway, the game is a LEGO-ish vehicle-building space-exploration sim: some things will have to be simplified for the sake of actual gameplay. As many others have noted, real life logic and physics does not necessarily translate into "fun" for a game. Yes, there are some things that make me go "WTF? Why...? How...?" but then I remember this is a game. If I want real-life engineering problems to solve, I'd go and try to solve real-life engineering problems instead of wasting time playing a "game". A lot of small details you mention I usually attribute to already being consolidated and included with a part and paid for in mass (and money if you're in career). If I'm using modular parts (the LEGO-ishness of this building system), I would assume all the parts have the necessary hardware and connections to function together as a whole: wiring, plumbing, etc.

I will admit I would like the functionality of some parts to have more use and meaning, but the metagame for KSP isn't all that developed yet... Though there's plenty of mods for the game to make up for that, though they are (mostly) at the mercy of the underlying game and engine. I would LOVE that ability to build, launch, and then recover a craft with it having (and keeping) a record of missions and re-using that EXACT SAME craft, kinda like Kerbal Construction Time. I get attached to craft designs I make, but not the actual crafts themselves since they aren't completely persistent. To approximate this in stock KSP would mean never actually recovering craft like SSTOs and/or Spaceplanes.

Also, one person's "illogical" is another person's "creative".

So really, as soon as 1.1 hits, SQUAD should get cracking on the things the player-base finds and reports. Once that dies down and they are satisfied with the game, THEN they should focus on putting on the flourishes to it. (Really, how many people bought this game just for the graphics? I got it for the gameplay...)

Actually, I wonder if SQUAD would consider a 2D version of KSP. I was recently reminded of a series of Flash games I used to play, "Into Space". I can imagine a "simplified" KSP game in 2D kinda like that.

16 minutes ago, StahnAileron said:

Actually, I wonder if SQUAD would consider a 2D version of KSP. I was recently reminded of a series of Flash games I used to play, "Into Space". I can imagine a "simplified" KSP game in 2D kinda like that.

It's not Squad's, but SimpleRockets fits that description pretty well.

Power sliding now possible?

I'll have to rebuild my Trophy Truck, Duna 1000 Rally, here I come!

On 1/29/2016 at 11:59 AM, TeeGee said:

Audio: Simulate what sound would really be like if we were to travel faster than the speed of sound and in vacuum of space. Proper rocket, rcs and airbreathing engine sounds please. IVA sounds. Comms chatter. 

Sound requires a medium (like air) to travel through. It is a wave of vibrations/changes in pressure through those air particles.  Obviously there is no air in the vacuum of space so no sound.

Inside the cabin where the Kerbals are, there is (pretend) air. So the IVA, Comms and such sounds do exist.  However that air (and the sound waves within it) is moving with the space ship.  This is a very different situation from on Earth where the air is traveling around Earth rather than with an airplane whose speed/direction would cause difference in pitch or sonic booms.

Edited February 1, 2016 by BevoLJ

1 hour ago, BevoLJ said:

Sound requires a medium (like air) to travel through. It is a wave of vibrations/changes in pressure through those air particles.  Obviously there is no air in the vacuum of space so no sound.

Inside the cabin where the Kerbals are, there is (pretend) air. So the IVA, Comms and such sounds do exist.  However that air (and the sound waves within it) is moving with the space ship.  This is a very different situation from on Earth where the air is traveling around Earth rather than with an airplane whose speed/direction would cause difference in pitch or sonic booms.

By "faster than the speed of sound and in vacuum of space" he was considering two separate cases: one case where the vehicle is supersonic in air, and another case when it is in space.

Sound varies considerably through the flight. The sound is at its loudest at launch and while near the ground because the launch installation structures and ground reflect sound towards the cabin. That, of course, drops rapidly! As a rocket gets higher astronauts have reported hearing wind noise. There is, of course, a sonic boom - after which engine noise drops somewhat because the crew no longer hear engine noise carried up through outside air. The changes in SRB thrust (where appropriate) and jettison also contribute to a reduction in engine noise. There is a further drop in audible engine noise with reducing air density and loss of fuel, as air and fuel within the rocket structures both act to transmit sound up to the cabin. Shuttle crew have reported that wind noise becomes quite significant compared to engine noise at high altitude, though that dies off as altitude increases further.

The funny thing is there is a sound mod that simulates proper sound effect at speed and in space. (Sorta very vaguely and indirectly alluding to in my "there are mods" statement.) Now, I know there are the diehard IVA players, but many people play external view. Mainly because it's the default view, but also because it's practical. (IVA mode is essentially useless without mods: ASET and/or RPM.) Assuming sound effects are based on where the camera (a.k.a. the player) is located, you will get no sound for the majority of situations. Space cannot conduct sound. In air, if you're supersonic, you have to be outside the shock cone to hear anything externally (uh, do correct me if I'm wrong about that last one...)

"Realistic sound" is almost an oxymoron in relation to typical KSP gameplay (sound in space?). Unless Squad makes this an Astronaut Simulator, proper sound effects (especially for space) is not very useful. Now, I would like SOME sound effects in general for certain things. RCS use is one of them (so I know/get reminds when my RCS is still active). But there is no need to "Simulate what sound would really be [...] in vacuum of space" (again, no sound in space.) If they expand IVA mode, sure, but let's get the core game up, running, and debugged first.

not really sure about the new wheels spinning out. but I use them in a rather unique way. i'll mod my own mods so.. its happy enough

one of the things I wanted to raise though.. a "mod" that should be stock by all accounts.. rover wheel sound mod sprang up around 0.25.. thankfully worked up until .90 without change then someone fixed it again.. with all these changes rover wheels shouldnt be so silent.. I love rover wheel mod for realistic traction motor effects, can even tell when a wheels slipping or not getting enough power.. the same thing would translate to any rover.. its just one of these little things that adds so much immersion to the game.. makes me wonder why it was left out, especially since the rovers on the kerbal animations have sounds?

 

odd to note that ive always increased the lateral forces in the wheel config file myself.. prevents trains from snaking and they track better at speed .. which is a milder version of what planes do with the slightest of errors in wheels on takeoff

Edited February 1, 2016 by Overland

I'm glad the wheels's super-friction is being fixed, it just made driving rovers and taking-off/landing planes way harder than it should be.

Less tipping over, more drifting.

Edited February 1, 2016 by Vurucore
